facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 893 of 1973 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 893 of 1973.

facts.text: The appeal arose from the judgment and order dated 18th April 1973 of the Delhi High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 289 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and order dated the 18th April, 1973 of the Delhi High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 289 of 1972.

facts.text: Elections to the Delhi Municipal Corporation were held on May 2, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The elections to the Delhi Municipal Corporation were held on May 2, 1973.

facts.text: Appellant, Benarsi Dass and Sumer Chand (Respondent 1) and others contested the election from Ward No.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant, Benarsi Dass and Sumer Chand, Respondent 1 and others companysted the election from Ward No.

facts.text: The appellant secured 3974 valid votes as against 3882 valid votes obtained by Respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant secured 3974 valid votes as against 3882 valid votes obtained by Respondent 1.

facts.text: The appellant was declared duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared duly elected.

facts.text: Respondent 1 filed an election petition under S. 15 of the Corporation Act before the Election Tribunal (District Judge).

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 filed an election petition under S. 15 of the Corporation Act before the Election Tribunal  District Judge

facts.text: The election petition challenged the election inter alia on the ground of corrupt practices particularised in para 9 of the petition.

anchor.surface_text: to challenge the election inter alia on the ground of companyrupt practices particularised in para 9 of the petition.

facts.text: The election-petitioner (Respondent 1) prayed that he be declared duly elected under S. 19(1)(c) of the Corporation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from getting the election of the returned candidate declared void, the election-petitioner prayed that he be declared duly elected

facts.text: In his written statement, the Returned Candidate (appellant) pleaded that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practices and disentitled to be declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: He further pleaded under the caption Additional Pleas that since the petitioner was guilty of the companyrupt practices, particularised in the written statement he had become disentitled

facts.text: The District Judge held that the appellant was not entitled to plead and prove that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge held that the appellant was number entitled to plead and prove in reply to the election petition that the petitioner was also guilty of companyrupt practices.

facts.text: The appellant filed a writ application under Article 226 of the Constitution in the High Court to impugn the orders of the District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: To impugn those orders of the District Judge, the appellant moved the High Court by a writ application under Article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The learned Single Judge dismissed the writ application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who tried the application negatived the companytention of the appellant and dismissed the writ application

facts.text: The appellant carried an appeal under cl. 10 of the Letters Patent to the Division Bench of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved,. the appellant carried an appeal under cl. 10 of the Letters Patent to the Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: The Division Bench dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Bench dismissed the appeal holding that in the absence of a specific provision

facts.text: The High Court granted certificate under Article 133(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted the certificate under Article 133 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: The Division Bench held that there is no provision in the Corporation Act corresponding to s. 97 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 allowing recrimination.

anchor.surface_text: holding that in the absence of a specific provision in the Corporation Act companyresponding to s. 97 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, the Returned Candidate is number entitled

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: M. Singhvi, S. S. Dhanduja and K. B. Rohatgi.

anchor.surface_text: M. Singhvi, S. S. Dhanduja and K. B. Rohatgi, for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent No. 1: P. Malhotra, Sat Pal, K. N. Sehgal and N. S. Das Behl.

anchor.surface_text: P. Malhotra, Sat Pal, K. N. Sehgal and N. S. Das Behl, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by SARKARIA, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKARIA, J.

facts.text: Returned candidate raised preliminary objections in written statement which have not been pressed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In his written statement, the Returned Candidate raised some preliminary objections  which have number been pressed before us

facts.text: Other grounds of appeal have not been pressed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The other grounds of appeal have number been pressed before us.
under Article 226 of the Constitution.
Article 133 1  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who tried the application negatived the contention of the appellant and dismissed the writ application with these observations - The petitioner may show that the Respondent No. 1 did not obtain a majority of valid votes. This is the legitimate defence. But he cannot go further and show that even if the Respondent No. 1 has obtained a majority of votes, the Respondent No. 1 is not entitled to be declared to be duly elected candidate because he committed corrupt practices.

arguments.claim: ubi jus ibi remedium: if right to plead s.9 disqualification, cannot debar evidence; else no remedy due to s.21 finality and s.33 circuitous

anchor.surface_text: The first is ubi jus ibi remedium where there is a right, there is a remedy. The argument is that once it is conceded that the returned candidate has a right to plead that the petitioner had incurred any of the disqualifications enumerated in S. 9, he cannot be debarred from leading evidence to substantiate that plea.

arguments.claim: right to recriminate cannot be spelled from s.9(1)(d); plea is recrimination under s.17(1)(b) not disqualification under s.17(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Corporation Act corresponding to S. 97 of the People Act, expressly giving a right of recrimination to the returned candidate. The question therefore, is Can such a right be legitimately spelled out of s.9 1   d ?

arguments.claim: 'to have been guilty' in s.9(1)(d) means immediately prior to election per Stroud and Re Storie

anchor.surface_text: But the effect of the word being appears to have been largely off-set by the use of the words to have been guilty in clause d . Strouds Judicial Dictionary gives the meaning of the phrase have been as immediately prior to a specific time. In Re storie, a scheme for the management of the Charity declared that the boys should be chosen from those boys who shall have been three years at the Free School.

arguments.claim: s.19 limits inquiry to whether petitioner received majority valid votes; valid votes distinct from corrupt practices s.22

anchor.surface_text: As will be apparent from s.19, quoted earlier, the tribunal i.e. the District Judge can pass only three kinds of final orders indicated in clauses a , b and c of sub-section 1 of that section. ... That is to say, he has to confine his enquiry to the determination of either of these two questions namely a whether in fact the petitioner received a majority of the valid votes,

arguments.claim: election contest statutory proceeding; strict construction required; no common law powers; cannot supply casus omissus or apply ubi jus/mischief rule

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly held that an election contest is not an action at law or a suit in equity but a purely statutory proceeding unknown to common law and the court possesses no common law powers. Statutory provisions of election law are to be, strictly construed and its requirement strictly observed.

arguments.claim: recrimination is statutory right unknown to common law; absent provision like s.97 RPA, not available per Jabar Singh v Genda Lal

anchor.surface_text: A right to file an election petition or a recriminatory petition which, in substance, is a counter-election- petition, being the mere creature of statute, unknown to common law, the appellant, in the absence of a clear statutory provision, is not entitled to recriminate on any of the grounds mentioned in section 17.

holdings.text: the returned candidate is not entitled to plead and prove that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practice in the election in question, and was therefore not entitled to be declared as duly elected

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Corporation Act corresponding to S. 97 of the People Act, expressly giving a right of recrimination to the returned candidate. The question therefore, is Can such a right be legitimately spelled out of s.9 1   d ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific statutory provision like s.97 RPA; plea is recrimination under s.17(1)(b), not disqualification under s.17(1)(a); affirmed lower courts

holdings.text: a right to recriminate cannot be legitimately spelled out of s.9(1)(d)

anchor.surface_text: Thus a right to recriminate cannot be legitimately spelled out of S. 9  1   d  without doing violence to its language or unduly stretching it. The above interpretation fits better in the general scheme of the Corporation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'to have been guilty' means prior to election; textual interpretation with precedents like Stroud and Re Storie; fits s.19 scheme

holdings.text: the phrase found to have been guilty in s.9(1)(d) is construed in the context of clause (a) of s.17(1), it will mean found to have been guilty at the time of the election, and immediately preceding the election

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, also, if the phrase found to have been guilty in s.9 1   d  is construed in the context of clause a  of s.17 1 , then on the analogy of Re Storie, it will mean found to have been guilty at the time of the election, and immediately preceding the election

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stroud's Dictionary and Re Storie precedent; harmonious construction with s.17(1)(a)

holdings.text: the District Judge has to confine his enquiry to the determination of either of these two questions namely (a) whether in fact the petitioner received a majority of the valid votes, or (b) whether the petitioner would have but for the votes obtained by the returned candidate, obtained a majority of the valid votes

anchor.surface_text: That is to say, he has to confine his enquiry to the determination of either of these two questions namely  a  whether in fact the petitioner received a majority of the valid votes, or  b  whether the petitioner would have but for the votes obtained by the returned candidate, obtained a majority of the valid votes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited by text of s.19(1)(c) and (2); valid votes distinct from corrupt practices under s.22

holdings.text: the answer to this question must be in the negative

anchor.surface_text: Having seen that there is no provision in the Corporation Act which specifically or by inevitable implication gives to a returned candidate a right to recriminate, the further question to be determined is Whether the court is competent to provide this casus omissus by invoking the maxim ubi jus ibi remedium or Mischief Rule or other principles of common law ? It appears to us that the answer to this question must be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election law strictly construed; statutory proceeding, no common law/equity powers; precedents like P. Malai Chami

holdings.text: an election contest is not an action at law or a suit in equity but a purely statutory proceeding unknown to common law and the court possesses no common law powers. Statutory provisions of election law are to be, strictly construed

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly held that an election contest is not an action at law or a suit in equity but a purely statutory proceeding unknown to common law and the court possesses no common law powers. Statutory provisions of election law are to be, strictly construed and its requirement strictly observed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeatedly held by this Court; applies to reject common law maxims like ubi jus ibi remedium, mischief rule, casus omissus

holdings.text: the appellant, in the absence of a clear statutory provision, is not entitled to recriminate on any of the grounds mentioned in section 17

anchor.surface_text: A right to file an election petition or a recriminatory petition which, in substance, is a counter-election- petition, being the mere creature of statute, unknown to common law, the appellant, in the absence of a clear statutory provision, is not entitled to recriminate on any of the grounds mentioned in section 17.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recrimination creature of statute; precedent Jabar Singh v Genda Lal

holdings.text: we would affirm the view taken by the Division Bench of the High Court in regard to the returned candidates claim to recriminate

anchor.surface_text: If the failure to comply strictly with the requirements of a statutory provision as to recrimination, precludes the returned candidate from recriminating, a fortiori, in the absence of such a statutory provision in an election law, the returned candidate has no right to recriminate. For the foregoing reasons, we would affirm the view taken by the Division Bench of the High Court in regard to the returned candidates claim to recriminate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative foregoing reasons; affirms lower court

anchor.surface_text: The second principle relied on by the Counsel is the Mischief Rule as enunciated in Heydons case 1 , that the companyrt should make such companystruction as shall suppress the mischief, and advance the remedy. The main object of these statutory provisions, it is urged, is to ensure  1   1584  3 Co. Rep. purity of the elections, and if the returned candidate is number allowed to expose the companyrupt practices companymitted by the election-petitioner, himself, it would defeat that object of the statute.

precedents.cited_proposition: Mischief Rule: the court should make such construction as shall suppress the mischief, and advance the remedy

anchor.surface_text: Strouds Judicial Dictionary gives the meaning of the phrase have been as immediately prior to a specific time. In Re storie, 1  a scheme for the management of the Charity declared that the boys should be chosen from those boys who shall have been three years at the Free School. A companyplaint was made that an undue election had been made. On appeal, Lord Justices Knight Bruce and Turner, companystruing the scheme, held that only those boys were eligible who had been three years at the school at the time of, and immediately preceding the election-  Emphasis supplied .

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'have been' as immediately prior to a specific time; boys who 'shall have been' three years at school means at the time of and immediately preceding the election
precedents.cited_holding: only those boys were eligible who had been three years at the school at the time of, and immediately preceding the election

precedents.citation: P. Malai Chami v. M. Andi Ambalam and ors. 1 A. I. R. 1973 S. C. 2077

anchor.surface_text: In P. Malai Chami v. M. Andi Ambalam and ors., 1  this Court speaking through Alagiriswami J., again pointed out A. I. R. 1973 S. C. 2077. -L954Sup.CI/74 .lm15 Courts in general are averse to allow justice to be defea- ted on a mere technicality. But in deciding an election petition, the High Court is merely a tribunal deciding an election dispute. Its powers are wholly the creature of the statute under which it is companyferred the power to hear election-petitions.

precedents.case_name: P. Malai Chami v. M. Andi Ambalam
precedents.cited_proposition: election contest is purely statutory proceeding unknown to common law; courts must strictly construe election law

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered-to use the oft-quoted words of Grover j. in Tauntons case 1 - that although the object of the statute by which the elec- tion tribunals were created was to prevent companyrupt practices, still the tribunal is a judicial, and number an inquisitorial one, it is a companyrt to hear and determine according to law, and number a companymission armed with powers to enquire into and suppress companyruption. In the light of these well-established principles, it is clear that the companyrt cannot bridge the gap or supply this apparent omission in the Corporation Act with regard to a returned candidates claim to recriminate, by importing principles of companymon law or equity,

precedents.cited_proposition: election tribunal is judicial and not inquisitorial; it is a court to hear and determine according to law, not a commission to enquire into corruption

precedents.citation: Jabar Singh v. Genda Lal 2  1964 6, S. C. R. 54

anchor.surface_text: We will close the discussion by referring to Jabar Singh v. Genda Lal 2 , wherein Gajendragadkar C.J. clarified the nature of the right of recrimination thus There are, however, cases in which the election petition makes a double claim it claims that the election of the re- turned candidate is void, and also asks for a declaration that the petitioner himself or some other person has been duly elected. It is in regard to such a companyposite case that S. 100 as well as s. 101 would apply, and it is in respect of the additional claim for a declaration that some other candidate has been duly elected that s. 97 companyes into play.

precedents.cited_proposition: nature of recrimination under s.97 RP Act: returned candidate can raise pleas attacking validity of election of alternative candidate claimed by petitioner; principle applies to composite petitions
precedents.cited_holding: when returned candidate recriminates, he becomes an inter-petitioner challenging validity of election of alternative candidate; strict compliance with s.97 required

anchor.surface_text: Having seen that there is no provision in the Corporation Act which specifically or by inevitable implication gives to a returned candidate a right to recriminate, the further question to be determined is Whether the court is competent to provide this casus omissus by invoking the maxim ubi jus ibi remedium or Mischief Rule or other principles of common law ? It appears to us that the answer to this question must be in the negative.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: If the failure to comply strictly with the requirements of a statutory provision as to recrimination, precludes the returned candidate from recriminating, a fortiori, in the absence of such a statutory provision in an election law, the returned candidate has no right to recriminate. For the foregoing reasons, we would affirm the view taken by the Division Bench of the High Court in regard to the returned candidates claim to recriminate.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
